comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: William K. Benson, president of the Detroit Federation of Labor in 1910, and Charles Wachtmeister, business agent of the Iron Workers' union, were accused in the „dynamite conspiracy“ trial, see e.g. The San Francisco call., December 11, 1912, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1912-12-11/ed-..., Column 5 San Francisco Call, Volume 112, Number 123, 1 October 1912 cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19121001.2.38# Bisbee daily review., October 10, 1912, Page PAGE TWO chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024827/1912-10-10/ed-... (with photo of Benson) Charles Wachtmeister was invicted to one year and one day in prison. The Day book., December 30, 1912, Page 7f chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1912-12-30/ed-... A. Entenza is most likely Antonio P. Entenza, a lawyer of Detroit, see Maurice Sugar: Law, Labor, and the Left in Detroit, 1912-1950 by Christopher H. Johnson, Page 54 books.google.ch/books?id=6uyBoG8-qMQC&pg=PA54&lpg... New-York tribune., April 16, 1920, Page 6, Column 6&7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-04-16/ed-...
